 Video ID: QPZ0pIK_wsc

 Video published at: 2017-07-31T15:00:04Z

Description: 
 There are a lot of opinions on how to hire coders, and most of them are terrible. The opinions, that is, not the coders. But a basic filter test to make sure someone can do what they say they can: that seems reasonable, and FizzBuzz is one of the more common tests. Even now, interviewers use it. Let's talk about why it's tricky, and how to solve it.

Imran's blog post: https://imranontech.com/2007/01/24/using-fizzbuzz-to-find-developers-who-grok-coding/

Other approaches for pretty much every language: http://rosettacode.org/wiki/FizzBuzz

Thanks to the Cambridge Centre for Computing History: http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/

The thing behind me is their Megaprocessor: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EMO3dZAizb4

And thanks to my proofreading team!

I'm at http://tomscott.com
on Twitter at http://twitter.com/tomscott
on Facebook at http://facebook.com/tomscott
and on Snapchat and Instagram as tomscottgo

119: Mark Reynolds 
 The use of “i” as the index for loops is historical.  In the 1960s and 1970s Fortran was the dominate programming language.  It is the precursor of most languages today.  Fortran used variables that started with i,j,k,l,m and n as default integer variables.  Programmers got into the habit of using these single letter variables as simple integer variables in loops so they did not have to go back and add them to their integer declarations. Over time this became so widely used that everyone started assuming that if they saw these single character variables then they were index variables in loops.  That coding habit moved with the programmer as they moved to new languages.

178: Sayven 
 Okay, but what if they say that the &quot;Buzz&quot; in &quot;FizzBuzz&quot; should not be capitalized? Also there&#39;s the problem that you want to avoid adding to strings, they are in a lot of languages unmutable and even if not, depending on the interpreter/compiler, it might be possible that you have to reallocate the string because it doesn&#39;t fit in the space you previously reserved for it. Passing a string directly to the print function might also avoid copying it later on when you print the constructed string.<br>Also, constant variables are a concept that is relevant here. You could make 5 or 3, or even &quot;Fizz&quot; and &quot;Buzz&quot; a constant variable. Like that you wouldn&#39;t have to change it for each time the variable occurs, just once.<br>The test has of course the problem that programs, or even modules, that are simple don&#39;t have to be designed like a complex module would. If it grows later on, be sure to changed that, but in such a case it would be too much.<br><br>Btw, my, fairly standard (imo), variant:<br><br>for i in range(1, 101):<br>	if i % 5 == 0:<br>		if i % 3 == 0:<br>			print(&quot;fizzbuzz&quot;)<br>		else:<br>			print(&quot;buzz&quot;)<br>	elif i % 3 == 0:<br>		print(&quot;fizz&quot;)<br>	else:<br>		print(i)<br><br><br>Note that the only duplication of values/code is 1) testing i % 3 == 0 twice, and 2) having &quot;fizz&quot; and &quot;buzz&quot; in both the individual versions and their combined version.<br><br>Also, using list comprehension: print(*[(&quot;fizzbuzz&quot; if i % 5 == 0 else &quot;fizz&quot;) if i % 3 == 0 else (&quot;buzz&quot; if i % 5 == 0 else i) for i in range(1, 101) ], sep=&#39;\n&#39;)

 For my R solution, I just used vectorization instead of loops. <br><br><br># Give the outputs for the game of FizzBuzz<br><br>x &lt;- 1:100 # Input integers<br>y &lt;- as.character(x)<br>y[x %% 3 == 0] &lt;- &quot;Fizz&quot;<br>y[x %% 5 == 0] &lt;- &quot;Buzz&quot;<br>y[x %% 15 == 0] &lt;- &quot;FizzBuzz&quot;<br><br>cat(y, sep = &quot;\n&quot;)<br><br><br># Allowing for more words<br>x &lt;- 1:100 # Input integers<br>y &lt;- paste0(rep(&quot;&quot;, length(x)),<br>            ifelse(x %% 3, &quot;&quot;, &quot;Fizz&quot;),<br>            ifelse(x %% 5, &quot;&quot;, &quot;Buzz&quot;),<br>            ifelse(x %% 7, &quot;&quot;, &quot;Fuzz&quot;),<br>            ifelse(x %% 11, &quot;&quot;, &quot;Bizz&quot;),<br>            ifelse(x %% 13, &quot;&quot;, &quot;Biff&quot;)<br>           )<br>y &lt;- ifelse(y == &quot;&quot;, as.character(x), y) # <br><br>cat(y, sep = &quot;\n&quot;)<br><br><br><br># Removing some repetition<br>special &lt;- function(x, n, word) {<br>  ifelse(x %% n, &quot;&quot;, word)<br>}<br>x &lt;- 1:100 # Input integers<br>y &lt;- paste0(rep(&quot;&quot;, length(x)),<br>            special(x, 3, &quot;Fizz&quot;),<br>            special(x, 5, &quot;Buzz&quot;),<br>            special(x, 7, &quot;Fuzz&quot;),<br>            special(x, 11, &quot;Bizz&quot;),<br>            special(x, 13, &quot;Biff&quot;)<br>           )<br>y &lt;- ifelse(y == &quot;&quot;, as.character(x), y) # <br><br>cat(y, sep = &quot;\n&quot;)<br><br># Could loop over a named vector<br>words &lt;- list(&quot;Fizz&quot; = 3, &quot;Buzz&quot; = 5, &quot;Fuzz&quot; = 7, &quot;Bizz&quot; = 11, &quot;Biff&quot; = 13)<br>x &lt;- 1:100 # Input integers<br>y &lt;- paste0(rep(&quot;&quot;, length(x)))<br>for(word in names(words)) {<br>  y &lt;- ifelse(x %% words[[word]], y, paste0(word, y))<br>}<br>y &lt;- ifelse(y == &quot;&quot;, as.character(x), y) # <br>cat(y, sep = &quot;\n&quot;)

Most people try to follow some variation of the &quot;clean code&quot; ideas.  I didn&#39;t learn this game until college, where it was a drinking game with a bunch of people in a circle.  The numbers were 5 (&quot;Fizz&quot;) and 7 (&quot;Buzz&quot;) and the additional rules were not merely if it were a multiple of 5/7 but also if it contained 5/7.  Thus, 17 is &quot;Buzz&quot; because it has a 7 in it.  Plus, except for 5 and 7, you needed to do both.  Thus, 15 is &quot;FizzFizz&quot; because it is divisible by 5 and has a 5 in it.  At most, you use only two descriptors with &quot;FizzBuzz&quot; having priority.  Thus, 55 is simply &quot;FizzFizz&quot; rather than &quot;FizzFizzFizz&quot; because you only do two and 35 is &quot;FizzBuzz&quot; rather than &quot;FizzFizzBuzz&quot; because you not only do only two but also &quot;FizzBuzz&quot; takes priority over &quot;FizzFizz.&quot;<br><br>1, 2, 3, 4, Fizz, 6, Buzz, 8, 9, Fizz, 11, 12, 13, Buzz, FizzFizz, 16, Buzz, 18, 19, Fizz, Buzz, 22, 23, 24, FizzFizz, 26, Buzz, Buzz...

791: Chris Mitchell 
 I haven&#39;t read all 6000 comments, so I&#39;m sure someone has already mentioned this - but in the dim and distant past, FORTRAN had a primitive typing rule: variables were real, except for those beginning with the letters I to N. So COUNT would be a real number, but KOUNT would be an integer. For simple variable like indices, it was easier (and fewer keystrokes when you&#39;re making punched cards or a paper tape) to use a single letter. Thus the convention became &quot;use I, J, K, ,and so on for counters&quot;. I and N were particularly popular as many programmers came from a maths background, where I (actually a rather fancy I with a double vertical stroke) was the set of integers, and N (fancy N) the set of natural numbers. K was popular among non-mathematicians for counters (probably because of the &quot;K&quot; sound in &quot;count&quot;) and often used in BASIC.

 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QPZ0pIK_wsc&amp;t=2m50s">2:50</a> the letter &quot;i&quot; stands for &quot;index&quot; because, in traditional for-loops like this one, you use it to go through an array of values where &quot;i&quot; is the index of the value you want to access the the array. It&#39;s shorter and easier to read &quot;myArray[i]&quot; than &quot;myArray[index]&quot;. Single-character variable names are usually frowned upon but for-loops like these are an exception.<br><br>Additionally, it fits the math conventions quite nicely. When working with matrices, a mathematician usually uses letters &quot;i&quot;, &quot;j&quot; and &quot;k&quot; to describe the columns and rows of a matrix or tensor. I think it&#39;s for the same reason, &quot;i&quot; stands for &quot;index&quot; in math too.

 As typically stated, the problem is deliberately underspecified.  Rather than immediately trying to code a solution, the developer should ask whether the solution is to be optimized for time, for space, for readability, for maintainability, for testability, for generality (ranges other than 1 to 100, divisors other than 3 and 5, and more than two divisors).  These characteristics can be conflicting, and different prioritization of the objectives will necessarily lead to different solutions.  For example, if run time is of the essence and the parameters won&#39;t change (1, 100, 3, 5), then simply code a single print statement with a multiline string literal as the argument, and you&#39;re done.

 For infinitely expandable sequence of number and their corresponding string and to output the combination of all truthful items for each term, you want two arrays. One with the numbers, the other with the strings.<br>You append output as you do in your last iteration, but do so inside a loop that go through the length of the array. If any evaluation on the numerical array returns true, append.<br>In fact, I&#39;d make it a function that intakes the two arrays, which the invoker can specify in any way it wishes. Be it fixed, as is the examples, or variable via an input script.<br><br>static void superFizzBuzz(List&lt;int&gt; numbers, List&lt;String&gt; terms, int start, int limit) {<br>  for (int i=start; i&lt;limit; i++) {<br>    String output = &quot;&quot;;<br>    for (int j=0; j&lt;numbers.size(); j++) { //I think this can also be &quot;for (int j : numbers)&quot; but... I have never done that for primitive type arrays, only object arrays so... I&#39;m not sure.<br>      if (i%numbers[j] == 0) {<br>        output += terms[j];<br>      }<br>    }<br>    if (output.equals(&quot;&quot;)) {<br>      output += i;<br>    }<br>    System.out.println(output);<br>  }<br>} <br><br>The best coding practice, however, is to <b>not</b> bake in expandability unless you <b>know</b> that it can exist. Because you end up with unnecessarily complicated code with unused features that makes it harder to understand and maintain by someone else. For example, anyone seeing the above program would not realize that it&#39;s for fizzbuzz immediately(leaving aside the name of the function anyhow). So the best programmer, upon hearing the task, is the one that asks the interviewer if there is likely to be any future modification or expandability and what they are if there is any and code accordingly. In fact, had the number range be small enough, say 30 or less, it might actually be advantageous to hard code the prints, it could be potentially be less resource intensive to run(not to say that this is a particularly difficult program to run but....)

1237: kxmode 
 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QPZ0pIK_wsc&amp;t=2m35s">2:35</a> The way I understand it from my experience is that programmers use &quot;i&quot; in loops because it&#39;s universal shorthand for &quot;iterator.&quot; It reminds programmers what the variable means and where they are in their code. Likewise, variable x and y typically appear for key-value pairs or some other pairing. Variable x, by itself, becomes a catch-all placeholder, an unknown that we use as a bucket to put values in. X and y are also used for grid math, and z when we&#39;re working with 3D vectors. Variables like k, l, a, b tend to be one-offs that serve a quick purpose within the private scope of a given function, loop, or another encapsulation. You may also see them in obfuscated code where a utility has converted all the uniquely named code into something illegible. When I write code, I like to use i, x, y, z, k, l, a, and b. Beyond that, I like using names that make sense to me as often as possible. Too many single-letter variables can make code unruly and hard to read.

1760: Brooke King 
 People use i for counters because in mathematics and especially sets we talk about “for any integer, i,” sometimes in reference to a range of sequential values for i. We use j and k (and sometimes more letters depending on depth) for nested loop counters because those are the letters after i. But I have always deviated from that tradition because there sometimes are i, j, or k in the spelling of more meaningful variables and values, like a boolean valued “inside,” a container object “jar,” or a text string “What’s the frequency, Kenneth.” Searching code for the counter variables is tedious if they are just single letters so almost immediately I started using double letters, ii, jj, and kk because they are easy both to spot and to search for.<br><br>Incidentally, if one has loops nested deeply enough to need even three counter variables and a data set of any significant size, reconsider the algorithm because it’s looking like O(n**3).

2090: Jonathan Guthrie 
 If I&#39;m interviewing you and I tell you to write the FizzBuzz program and you go to a lot of trouble to make it easy to modify, you won&#39;t gain any points.  Not with me anyway.  I might ask you what sort of thing you would do to change one of the numbers, or to add other numbers, but unless I tell you that the program is going to eventually need to replace the multiples of lots of different primes with words, I&#39;d be looking for the simplest solution you can think of, even if it&#39;s a little more difficult to modify.  That&#39;s because even though modifications might be necessary, we have no requirement to make it more complicated right now.  Future-proofing this program, which obviously has no future, is entirely wasted effort.<br><br><br>The advice that is given is to write the program you&#39;re asked to write, not the one that you might need to write in the future.  The problem with that advice is that sometimes planning for the simplest solution tends to paint the developer into a corner.  For a simple program, it&#39;s easy to write a simple linear function with global variables and significant constants defined as  you go, but as programs get more complex, that becomes less workable and, for example, when (not if!) you get tired of recompiling every time some constant changes and want to make the program configurable, you&#39;ll need to do some redesign.  If it seems likely that a program will need to be extended in the future, a wise programmer does quick and easy things in the initial version to make that future program less work.<br><br><br>There is a balance to be struck between not doing any more design than absolutely necessary and building a whole bunch of extraneous crap that nobody will ever need.  In general, there are different approaches for problems of different complexity, and it is better to overestimate the complexity of the final program than to underestimate it, but the ideal situation is to use an approach that is appropriate for precisely the level of complexity of the final program.  It&#39;s just too bad that nobody knows how complex any program will eventually wind up being until is so far along that it&#39;s hard to fix. 

 	Replies: ['Jonathan Guthrie', '@AllUpOns Saying &quot;KISS&quot; misses my larger point.  An awful lot of programming is dealing with different aspects of an incredibly complicated universe.  The goal is for your design to be appropriate for the complexity of the actual problem you&#39;re trying to solve.  If you write a simple solution, I&#39;m going to ask you what approaches you might take to solve a more complicated problem, with the expectation that you would show me stuff like what Mr. Scott does.  You shouldn&#39;t assume that any problem is complicated, but you can&#39;t really assume that it&#39;s not, either.  The best program designs are simple, but can be extended in obvious ways in case the problem turns out to be more complicated than we thought.', 'AllUpOns', 'In other words, KISS. <br>Keep It Simple, Stupid.']

2099: Nonetheless Zero 
 Just saw this video years after it was posted. Fascinating. But I totally disagree with the premise of the interview question. When I interview potential employees, I tell them what I expect and see if they can do it. No secret evaluation criteria. There are times I want a job done fast and efficiently. I don&#39;t care how it is done, just get it done now so we can move on. This interview assignment is a children&#39;s game. The rules won&#39;t change in the future. Get it done fastest and get on to the next task. On the other hand, if I want something done that needs to be open to dynamic adjustment in the future, I should say so. While it sounds very clever to say that all programming should be done in a way that allows a programmer in five years to do something with it, there are lots of situations where the code is never likely to be revisited, so don&#39;t invest in a very low probability future outcome. Sure, if it&#39;s all the same in time and effort, make it more dynamic. Sure, you should always do work in a way where other employees can easily see what you did. In practice, though, you need to balance resource use (particularly time) with these goals. If you want the interviewee to show a particular ability, then tell them what it is. It let&#39;s you evaluate them more effectively and sends a clear message about what will be expected in the job.

2688: ratelslangen 
 Do<br>match (x % 3 == 0, x % 5 == 0) with<br>| (true, true) -&gt; &quot;Fizzbuzz&quot;<br>| (false, true) -&gt; &quot;Buzz&quot;<br>| (true, false) -&gt; &quot;Fizz&quot;<br>| (false, false) -&gt; x<br><br>No magic numbers, no repeated tests, concise, easy to understand, simple to maintain, strict 4 way switch.<br>Fizzbuzz is not a combination of two cases, there are four cases. Neither 3 or 5, only 3, only 5, both 3 and 5. It tricks you into thinking it is a combination of two cases by using the same words in the output, even though its really 4 cases. 

 	Replies: ['ratelslangen', 'Accounting for an extra number is easy, much easier than trying to maintain any of the other approaches. You would need to change the code for every other approach as well, and in this way you dont have to think about the order of operations with string concatination (you can never accidently get buzzfizz). It is a much cleaner approach than the other ones, and more reflective of the actual problem. You have a 4 way choice, this is a 4 way choice, much better than multiple interwoven and interacting if statements. And it is not a magic number, a magic number is a number that is used in multiple places but not saved as a constant named variable. It is only used once, hence its not a magic number.', 'Plasmaboo', 'You have the &quot;magic numbers&quot; right on the second line, 3 and 5.<br>It&#39;s concise, but not the most readable code. This is a short example, but imagine that approach to anything beyond trivial, whoever needs to maintain that after you will hate you; so no, it&#39;s not simple to maintain.<br>Also, if you&#39;re now told to also account for an extra number, you need to change everything.<br><br>You tried.']

2936: ManyCoreProgramming ManyCoreProgramming 
 Of course, FizzBuzz assumes that people should be thinking of architecture and the updating process all the time. What I think happens is that people choose the path of least resistance.<br><br>It&#39;s a small program that isn&#39;t expected to change that much? Quick-and-dirty usually works just fine.<br><br>You&#39;re working on creating the next-gen operating system? Architecture is a must.<br><br>So when they see a short list of simple product requirements (that don&#39;t even imply coding for the future), architecture isn&#39;t really going to matter. Scale the program up and they&#39;ll change priorities.<br><br>Hence why this test isn&#39;t indicative of how good a programmer is.<br><br>def fizzbuzz(k):<br> div3 = (k%3 == 0)<br> div5 = (k%5 == 0)<br> if (div3 and div5):<br>  print &quot;FizzBuzz&quot;<br> elif (div3):<br>  print &quot;Fizz&quot;<br> elif (div5):<br>  print &quot;Buzz&quot;<br> else:<br>  print k<br><br>def game(list_of_numbers, func):<br> for k in list_of_numbers:<br>  func(k)<br><br>game(range(1,101), fizzbuzz)<br><br>There, a simple python program that takes a univariate function and a list of numbers to play a game. At no point do I expect any changes. If there&#39;s a major change, no amount of abstraction would help (&quot;oh, you want a banking system now?&quot;). If there&#39;s a single minor change, it wouldn&#39;t take that long to modify the program. The only time you&#39;d consider changing the algorithm is when the update process simply doesn&#39;t scale anymore.<br><br>For example, insert sort is still fine for &lt;100 items despite being O(n^2) and if you&#39;ve always been dealing with &lt;100 items, then there&#39;s no need to change. If you&#39;re suddenly expecting or noticing an increase, then you might consider updating if there are scaling issues.<br><br>The same applies to the updating process and in turn, the architecture. Only change it when necessary, lest you&#39;d be wasting the company time and money on things that will never be needed.

 	Replies: ['ChevronTango', 'that presupposes that we are always going to 100. As Tom pointed out, you don&#39;t know how the function may change in the future. There&#39;s also little practical distinction in trading your divisions for a counter in memory. It might be more efficient for some calculations but the trade off is increased memory usage. This example would see little distinction between the two, and a counter would arguably over-complicate things for the person who came to maintain your code afterward, which is also an important factor. It&#39;s dangerous to assume you are the only one who will look at your code so you can write it however you like. All of this is a bit baseless as arguments since we are talking about a very childish function, but you can see hopefully how some of these considerations would play out on large more complex behaviors.']

4179: Dryued 
 You could probably write the program by using &quot;fizz&quot; and &quot;buzz&quot; counters. Increase them on every iteration; if any of them are maxed, output the corresponding string and reset the counter. If none are maxed, output the number.  	Replies: ['ChevronTango', 'Depends on the scale of what you are trying to do. For a simple problem like this, that&#39;s definitely overkill, and you should trust your compiler/interpreter to know how to optimize, particularly if you&#39;re within the limited scope of 32 bit signed integers and a relatively small test set. As your problem space increases, however, there will come a tipping point where it&#39;s arguably quicker to trade runtime calculations for memory. This is true of every application with a performance consideration. In this case you&#39;d be adding more calculations, some with constant runtime, some not, with the hopes that as you get bigger or more complex, your increased memory usage by storing these counters would pay off and allow these operations to run faster. Practically this would depend on your language and compiler, and as an interviewer, I wouldn&#39;t expect an applicant to do any of this, but understanding the risks and concerns that go along with this thinking when asked about it would be a big tick in their favor.']

 	Replies: ['FinBoyXD', '+James Nguyen Only difference that I can think of is that the i variable is not visible outside the for loop, but it is visible outside the while loop.', 'Rimrul', '&gt; The statement for (clause-1;expression-2;expression-3) statement behaves  as  follows:  The  expression expression-2 is  the  controlling  expression  that  is evaluated before each execution of the loop body.<br><br>--ISO/IEC 9899:201x Draft N1570<br><br>For a standard compliant  C compiler that means this has to be checked before the loop.', 'Chris Sloan', 'Lawri van Buël Are you saying that the Java complier will produce differently behaving code or just that the generated jvm code might put the instructions in various places?<br><br>Because c compilers can do just about anything they want in optimization as long as they implement the specified behavior, and I assume Java compilers (and most other languages) will be the same in that aspect.<br><br>But if you&#39;re saying that different Java implementations will interpret the specified behavior for the same for loop in the same source code in multiple ways, that&#39;s a bit of a surprise (assuming it&#39;s not just a bug, of course).', 'Lawri van Buël', 'Actually this is highly dependant on what language you use. in most ANSI C compilers you are correct. in Java its dependant on you JVM (for example on some JAVACard implementations this check is indeed the last call of a loop, in the form of a JMPNZ [Jump if not zero] instruction).<br>Javacript its dependant on your ECMAScript implementaion so basically you do not know.<br>But in Embedded C (or in optimised C) you simply do not know where the instruction is in the loop. 4361: PSquared1234 
 Programmers use &quot;i&quot; as the default counter name because of Fortran. By default variables starting with letters i and beyond (alphabetically) were &quot;implicitly&quot; integers (integer class by default). &quot;h&quot; would have been a floating point number by default, I think. 

 	Replies: ['Geneticus0', 'I use it because, to me, it means &quot;index&quot;.  I never programmed in Fortran. When I use loops, I&#39;m generally creating lists, filling arrays, etc.', 'Joey Carson', 'Kilgore Trout hahahah', 'Joey Carson', 'ConsciousAtoms this convention of prepending a certain letter is still in use today to be a sort of descriptive encoding of the data type.  In strongly typed languages like C/C++, it&#39;s important to understand the limitations of the data type as opposed to languages that support type coercion (forcing an objects type at runtime using methods like toString or toInt).  An example in C, would be stating that a variable name is a pointer to a null (zero) terminated string of wide (2 byte) characters is generally prefaced with pzsw (pointer zero terminated string of wide characters).  I don&#39;t recall the name, but this is considered part of an older but well known naming scheme.  I think it was created to be lexically symbolic of type before text search/visibility was as good as it is today, e.g. easier to understand without using primitively slow tools to look it up.', '007bistromath', 'same', 'Noah', 'I always think of it as an &quot;index&quot;.']
